facts.text: Suit filed for declaration and delivery of possession of 12 bighas, 16 kathas, 4 dhurs of land in Mauza Chhatahara in Santhal Parganas.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of a suit for declaration and delivery of possession of 12 bighas, 16 kathas, 4 dhurs of land in Mauza, Chhatahara in the District of Santhal Parganas.

facts.text: Plaintiffs and four defendants (2nd party) are successors in interest of Santokhi Jha who became owner of entire raiyati interest in these lands many years ago.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs and the four defendants, described in the plaint as defendants 2nd party, are the successors in interest of one Santokhi Jha who became owner of the entire raiyati interest in these lands many years ago.

facts.text: Santokhi Jha, after becoming raiyat, purchased by registered deed the entire interest of the Lakhirajdar under whom he was raiyat.

anchor.surface_text: Some time after he became a raiyat of this land, Santokhi purchased by a registered deed the entire interest of the Lakhirajdar under whom he was the raiyat.

facts.text: On May 15, 1935, lands sold by 2nd party defendants and plaintiffs 1 to 6 to present appellants.

anchor.surface_text: On May 15, 1935, these lands were sold by the 2nd party defendants and others including the plaintiffs 1 to 6, to the present appellants.

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed no interest passed to vendees because raiyati character existed and was inalienable under Regulation III of 1872.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that numberinterest passed to the vendees by that sale deed, because the raiyati character of the land was existing on the date of transfer and this was inalienable under the provisions of Regulation III of 1872.

facts.text: Plaintiffs pleaded 1935 transfer was fraudulent, collusive, and without legal necessity.

anchor.surface_text: It was further pleaded that this transfer of 1935 was fraudulent and companylusive and that there was numberlegal necessity for the transfer.

facts.text: Defendants first party denied fraud or collusion and pleaded transfer for legal necessity to pay antecedent debts, binding on plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants first party denied the allegations of fraud or companylusion and further pleaded that the transfer was made for legal necessity for paying antecedent debts of the family and they are therefore binding on the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Defendants pleaded lands were not raiyati but Bakasht lands of Malik on sale date, no bar under Regulation III of 1872.

anchor.surface_text: They also pleaded that the lands in the suit were number, on the date of the sale, raiyati but Bakasht lands of the Malik and so there was numberbar to the sale of these lands under the provisions of Regulation III of 1872.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge Dumka held sale justified by legal necessity, not fraudulent, binding on plaintiffs, land lost raiyati character, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge, Dumka, who tried the suit held that the sale was justified by legal necessity and that it was number fraudulent or companylusive. He further held that while the plaintiffs were number estopped from challenging the sale deed it was binding on them.

facts.text: District Judge Santhal Parganas agreed with Trial Court, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the plaintiffs the District Judge, Santhal Parganas, agreed with the findings of the Trial Court and held that the suit had been rightly dismissed.

facts.text: High Court appeal: legal necessity and no fraud not challenged; argument that raiyati interest continued despite acquisition of landlord interest.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs then appealed to the High companyrt of Judicature at Patna. Before the High Court the finding that the sale deed was for legal necessity and there was numberfraud or companylusion were number challenged.

facts.text: Banerjee J held raiyati interest continued, no merger, sale void re raiyati interest, allowed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge  Banerjee, J.  who heard the appeal, was of opinion that there was numberconflict between the several entries in the record of rights the first of which showed the lands as held by Santokhi as the raiyat while the later settlement records showed lands as Bakasht Malik and that in law the raiyati interest companytinued even after the raiyat acquired the superior landlords interest.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal by defendants first party unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The Letters Patent Appeal by the defendants Ist party from this decision was unsuccessful the learned Judges who heard the appeal being of opinion, in agreement with Mr. Justice Banerjee, that the raiyati interest recorded in the earlier settlement companytinued inspite of the entry Bakasht Malik in the subsequent Settlements

facts.text: High Court gave certificate under s.110 CPC and Art 135 Constitution for SC appeal.

anchor.surface_text: and the raiyati interest companyld number be alienated by the sale deed of May 15, 1935. The High Court, however, gave a certificate that as regards the value and nature of the case it fulfilled the requirements of s. 110 of the Code of Civil Procedure read with Article 135 of the Constitution of India and was a fit case for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Santokhi objected in Settlement Objection Case No. 41 of 1909, wanted land recorded as Bakasht Malik.

anchor.surface_text: In their attempt to show that Santokhi decided to treat raiyati interest as merged in the Lakhirajdar interest the appellants relied on Ex. I - a certified companyy of the order-sheet in Settlement Objection Case No. 41 of 1909.

facts.text: Settlement Officer approved entry of land as Bakasht Malik.

anchor.surface_text: The objection was made by Santokhi in respect of the entry in the record of rights of the land number in dispute. After stating that Santokhi purchased the Zamindari interest three years ago, the order reads thus Santokhi is number the Zamindar and the sole raiyat in the village.

anchor.surface_text: the first of which showed the lands as held by Santokhi as the raiyat while the later settlement records showed lands as Bakasht Malik

facts.text: Later settlement records showed lands as Bakasht Malik.

anchor.surface_text: while the later settlement records showed lands as Bakasht Malik and that in law the raiyati interest companytinued even after the raiyat acquired the superior landlords interest.

facts.text: Supreme Court held raiyati interest did not merge in proprietary interest.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that the raiyati interest did number merge in the proprietary interest.

facts.text: Supreme Court held sale of May 15, 1935 void with respect to raiyati interest.

anchor.surface_text: Our companyclusion therefore is that the High Court was right in holding that the sale of May 15, 1935 was void with respect to the raiyati interest and only the right to receive rent passed by this sale to the defendants first party.

facts.text: Right to transfer raiyati interest never recorded in record of rights.

anchor.surface_text: For, it is companymon ground that the right to transfer raiyati interest was never recorded in the record of rights as regards these lands.

facts.text: Santhal Parganas has community of village raiyats with preferential rights over village lands.

anchor.surface_text: The Santhal way of life favoured the emergence of a powerfull village companymunity with its special rights over all lands of the village. This companymunity of village raiyats has preferential and reversionary rights over all lands at the village whether cultivated or uncultivated.

facts.text: Alienation of raiyats holdings interdicted by government orders in 1887.

anchor.surface_text: It was in this state of things that the alienation of Raiyats holdings in any form was interdicted by Government orders in 1887.

facts.text: Regulation III of 1872 section 27 prohibits transfer of raiyati right unless recorded.

anchor.surface_text: 27.  1  No transfer by a raiyat of his right in his holding or any portion thereof, by sale, gift, mortgage, lease, or any other companytract or agreement, shall be valid unless the right to transfer has been recorded in the record of rights,
inalienable under the provisions of Regulation III of 1872.

issues.text: If a raiyat of lands in the District of Santhal Parganas acquires the entire superior landlords interests, does his raiyati interest cease to exist or does he continue to be a raiyat in addition to becoming a superior landlord?

anchor.surface_text: We can find no reason to think however that the provision of this relief was intended to be exhaustive...

arguments.claim: Raiyati interest did not merge; sale 1935 void re raiyati, only rent right passed

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion therefore is that the High Court was right in holding that the sale of May 15, 1935 was void with respect to the raiyati interest and only the right to receive rent passed by this sale to the defendants first party.

holdings.text: The raiyati interest did not merge in the proprietary interest.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No automatic merger under Indian law; intention required but no evidence of intention by Santokhi; Bakasht Malik entry neutral; special Santhal Parganas community interests and policy against alienation favor continuance.

holdings.text: The sale of May 15, 1935 was void with respect to the raiyati interest and only the right to receive rent passed by this sale to the defendants first party.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Raiyati interest continued; right to transfer never recorded in record of rights under Regulation III of 1872 s.27; transfers in contravention invalid and unrecognized by courts.

holdings.text: The legal position as regards merger is that while the union of superior and subordinate interests will not automatically cause a merger, merger will be held to have taken place if the intention to merge is clear and not otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position as regards merger, apart from these statutory provisions, may be stated thus. That while the union of the superior and subordinate interests will not automatically cause a merger, merger will be held to have taken place if the intention to merge is clear and not otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Influenced by English equity modifications; Indian cases reject automatic merger; courts look to intention, conduct, benefit, and duty to keep separate.

holdings.text: The evidence in this case does not show that Santokhi intended to merge the raiyati interest in the proprietary interest.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Settlement objection Ex.I shows desire for Bakasht Malik entry meaning cultivation by owner, not negation of raiyati; to Santokhi's benefit and duty to keep separate under village community system.

holdings.text: The entry Bakasht Malik does not amount to a negation of the raiyati interest and is a neutral expression as regards the continuance or otherwise of raiyati interest.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Bakasht Malik means lands in cultivating possession of owner; does not imply end of raiyati status; no conflict with earlier raiyati entry.

holdings.text: The decision of the Settlement Officer that the land was Bakasht Malik does not operate as res judicata.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to challenge as Bakasht entry neutral and does not negate raiyati interest.

holdings.text: The question whether the raiyati interest continued to exist after Santokhi acquired the proprietary interest is a mixed question of law and fact.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Depends on correct appreciation of doctrine of merger as applicable to Santhal Parganas.

holdings.text: The civil court has jurisdiction; the provision under s.27(3) is not exhaustive and does not bar relief; courts must ignore invalid transfers under s.27(2).
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.27(2) obliges courts to ignore invalid transfers; s.27(3) discretionary eviction by DC additional, not exclusive.

holdings.text: The doctrine of merger does not apply to raiyati holders in the Santhal Parganas.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Special features: village community rights, headman duties, policy against alienation; raiyat bound to keep interests separate.

holdings.text: Sarda Devi v. Ram Louchan Bhagat was wrong if interpreted to hold that raiyati interest passes with landlord interest.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.27 prohibits transfer of raiyati interest; sale was of landlord interest only.

precedents.cited_proposition: presumption will exist against merger where it can be shown that it is either the duty or the interest of the person acquiring the outstanding estate that the two estates should be preserved as separate interests

precedents.cited_proposition: similar view to Noomesh that doctrine of merger does not apply

anchor.surface_text: Prosonna v. Jagat,  1878  3 C.L.R. 159

precedents.cited_proposition: while the union of the superior and subordinate interests might not automatically cause a merger of the latter in the former, the conduct of the party concerned might show that he did not intend to keep the two interests alive as mutually distinct rights and if this was shown, merger should be held to have taken place

precedents.cited_proposition: possibility of merger of resumable birt tenures in a superior interest, where the holder did not take steps to keep the two interests alive as distinct

precedents.cited_proposition: conduct of the party concerned showed that he did not intend to keep the two interests alive as mutually distinct rights the union of the superior and subordinate interests will result in merger of the latter in the former

anchor.surface_text: The legal position as regards merger, apart from these statutory provisions, may be stated thus.
